Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2010 03:51AM citykitty wrote: sohardbnme, thank you for laying out the chronology of your journey thus far.  I'm fairly newly diagnosed, and it's educational to see how one person's process can go, even if your situation isn't exactly like mine. I do hope you've been able to find support, both on this board and IRL.  I've been lucky to find help and understanding in the most unexpected places.  Coworkers I barely know have sat me down and told me all about their experiences.  A friend I don't know well had a survivor friend of hers email me.  A long-lost online friend showed up on Facebook one day, just coincidentally, to post about her fourth year being cancer-free, and she has been a wonderful source of information for me.  One day, I finally decided I would go get a massage for the first time, to address the stress I was feeling, and I mentioned to the therapist the source of my stress.  She too had a friend of hers contact me.  So you just never know.  But nothing beats having someone who's been there to ask questions of.  And since everyone's experience is a little different, I've found it really helpful to get the perspectives of multiple people. Of course you're nervous about your mastectomy!  I just had a lumpectomy and still might need a mastectomy in the end, and I'm nervous, too!  I just keep telling myself that all these other women have made it through, and so can we! And BTW, I agree with BarbaraA -- you look great bald!  Hugs and continued good wishes to you!
Posts.Title: Surgery Tommorow : No family support Ondagrow Renrel

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 03:40PM citykitty wrote: Beesie, thanks for a great post!   I'm just a few weeks post-uni mx with TE.  I wouldn't say I feel euphoric, but neither can I say I feel a huge sense of loss.  Your insight was really helpful -- good to know I may find that feeling many months or more down the road.  Now I can be prepared if it happens.  So far the greatest mental anguish for me has been before the surgery.  I had a difficult time deciding whether to do unilateral or bilateral, and reconstruction or not.  Once I got past that hurdle, the rest was cake (so far).  I don't feel horribly deformed when I look in the mirror -- just different from how I was.  Most of the time I view it as kind of a bizarre adventure.
Posts.Title: Mentally Preparing for Single Mastectomy aab CrunchyPoodleMama

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2010 08:22AM citykitty wrote: Hi, Deanna -- This may be more detail than you wanted, so be forewarned!  :)  I just had my lumpectomy with needle localization and sentinel lymph node biopsy last Friday.  This is actually my second such surgery.  I had a surgical biopsy about 2 months ago.  The lumpectomy last week was surgery #2, a re-excision of the site of my biopsy.  About a week before the surgery, I went in for pre-surgical testing.  This took only about an hour.  They took 3 small vials of blood, did an EKG which lasted only moments, and did a chest X-ray in two different positions.  A technician and a nurse both quizzed me on my general health, medications, etc.  Basically they are making sure you're good to go for surgery, checking for any issues that could affect anesthesia, etc. The day before my surgery, I went in for lymph node mapping.  A radioactive dye was injected into my breast.  It wasn't especially painful, just the normal prick you get with an injection.  I was able to leave the facility and had to return in two hours.  Then they did a scan.  I had to lie still under a big machine for about 10 minutes.  No big deal, and I even got to keep my clothes on for that one.  I was warned to stay about 3 feet away from pregnant women and small children for the next day or so, since I was radioactive.  Then I proceeded to get on a crowded NYC bus, haha!  I only realized that when it was too late -- but I was still within the instructions.  I was told my urine might turn blue -- and true enough, the next day my urine was indeed a lovely shade of aqua blue -- similar to one of those toilet bowl cleaners, only prettier! I couldn't eat anything after midnight the day before surgery, so I stayed up and had a late, substantial dinner to tide me through the next day! On Friday I had to be at the hospital at 8:30 for the needle localization, with surgery scheduled for high noon.  I changed into a hospital gown and robe, and waited with DH for a while till I had to go for the needle loc procedure.  They squished me into a mammo machine, took pictures, inserted three different needles, and took pictures again.  Of course the mammo was slightly uncomfortable.  I experienced a sharp pain with one of the three needles, but thankfully it was brief.  I also experienced a little dizziness, which came as quite a surprise to me, but the two doctors and the tech were just great and told me to take my time.  I'd had a similar needle loc for my biopsy surgery and did not experience any dizziness at all.  I consider myself pretty darn healthy so this was weird for me.  They taped down the three wires sticking out of my breast, and then I went back to wait with DH until my surgery time -- which ended up being about an hour later than planned.  By this time I was getting hungry.  I asked DH to make sure that afterward, I got to eat something better than graham crackers and apple juice (which is what I got after the biopsy and what we experienced twice more in the past several weeks since then).  He promised me tapas, and that really cheered me up!  Oh, and at some point during all this a nurse inserted an IV in the back of my hand, which is I guess where the anesthesia would go at the time of surgery. Before going into the OR, I had to put on a "hat" -- one of those goofy blue bonnets.  They make me feel really weird, but I guess when you're going into surgery it's par for the course.  In the OR, I saw my surgeon all gussied up for the procedure.  Behind her blue bonnet and mask, I saw her friendly smile and twinkling eyes and I felt better.  They had me lie on the table.  They covered me with a high-tech-looking blanket that was like a heated version of an inflatable swimming pool raft, and they put one of those oxygen tube things in my nose (I forget what it's called).  They untied the back of my gown, and the surgeon took a look at the breast.  One thing that was kind of funny:  They were having trouble reaching the anesthesiologist.  They were paging her through some kind of voice recognition system, but the system wasn't recognizing the name.  The person calling her kept saying to the computer voice: "No." And she'd have to keep repeating the name.  Everyone in the room was cracking up.  Although you might think it a little unsettling that they couldn't get the doctor, the laughter in the room did relieve my nervousness a little (and I didn't really think I was so nervous at the time).  Finally, as someone went out of the room to find the anesthesiologist, she actually walked in through another door!  They hooked up the anesthesia IV in my hand.  And that's about the last I remember until I woke up in the recovery room. It wasn't general anesthesia, but it was what they called "twilight sleep."  When I had foot surgery many years ago, my doctor called it "milk of amnesia."  You don't feel anything and you don't remember anything when you wake up. It was interesting to note a couple of differences between my biopsy surgery and this re-excision surgery, which were done by different doctors at different hospitals.  This just goes to show that different places do things different ways.  For my biopsy, the gown I was given was a large multilayered paper gown with a built-in heating feature.  I saw the doctor before going into the OR and talked with him briefly (and they had me sign my life away with a bunch of paperwork).  To go to the needle loc procedure, I was placed in a wheelchair, and to go to the OR, I was rolled in on a gurney.  I don't recall any fancy blanket like I had in the second surgery last week. For my re-excision, on the other hand, the hospital gave me a fabric tie-back gown and a robe to go over it. (These were well-worn, unlike the robes they've given me for other exams and procedures, which were really nice, new-looking seersucker.)  I signed the consent paperwork at the time the appointment was made, not the day of surgery when I was already under stress.  I didn't see the surgeon till I arrived at the OR (wish I could have seen her sooner, but oh, well).  To get to the needle loc and to get to the OR, I walked in my lovely hospital robe and socks.  The heated inflated blanket in the OR was definitely comforting. Anyway, after I recovered sufficiently, I got dressed.  I was really hungry, because it was now about 4 or 5 p.m. and I hadn't eaten all day.  I would have loved to have gone out for tapas -- but we ended up eating in the hospital cafeteria to wait out some rush hour traffic!  Haha!  Fortunately the food wasn't that bad.  I slept in the car, and thought I'd go home and go right to bed, but somehow I had a second wind and stayed up later than I planned.  The past few days, recovery has been good.  I took one Vicodin the first night, not because I was in pain, but because I didn't want to wake up in pain.  The second night I also took one around 2 a.m.; I was having a little trouble getting comfortable in bed.  Each successive day, the soreness has subsided significantly more, and I've felt less swelling under my arm from the lymph node incision.  I feel like I could go in to the office, but they are letting me work from home. I'm trying not to take too many days off work now, because I have a feeling I'll need them down the road! I have a follow-up with my surgeon 10 days from the surgery date to review the results and find out what comes next.  I still may need a mastectomy in the end, because of my particular situation (IDC plus DCIS found in the biopsy surgery, plus some DCIS found in post-biopsy mammo).  I'm fully expecting chemo, radiation, the works.  So we'll see.  Meanwhile, this weekend I hope to hold DH to his promise of tapas! I hope this helps.  Sorry it's so long.  It actually was helpful for me to record what happened, so thanks for giving me the impetus to do so!  Best wishes to you with your surgery and recovery!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy~ ur experience Deanna67 Deanna67

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 07:56AM citykitty wrote: Hi, all -- Forgive me, I'm just catching up with the last few pages of this thread.  Now that I'm done with chemo, I've been putting in a lot of extra time at work to make up for time I was out with a jillion doctor appts.  That means less time to check in here.  This week I'm home recovering from my exchange surgery, so I finally have a few free moments! Starting a couple of weeks before the end of chemo, I began what I now view as a new round of side effects.  First of all, I get hot flashes many times a day; really annoying at work.  Then, just when I was so pleased to have not lost much of my eyebrows and eyelashes -- surprise!  The eyebrows are disappearing rapidly, and I fear the lashes are not far behind.  A friend who hadn't seen me asked if my wig had gotten lighter; I assume it was the eyebrows that were different.  I use an eyebrow pencil and my wig has bangs, and that's about all I can do about that.  Also, my nails are a mess.  It began with one tender little pink spot on the middle finger of my right hand.  Over a period of weeks my nails became painful; it hurt even to reach for something in my purse or file my nails.  Now they don't hurt, but most my nails are discolored to a greater or lesser degree.  That first nail now has a big dark brown spot the size of a pencil eraser, and another lighter brown spot almost as big.  The ring finger nail is about 1/3 brown.  The rest are mostly just lighter brown.  My oncologist pointed out that the new growth at the base of the nailbed looks good, though, so hopefully it's just a matter of waiting it out. In the meantime, it's particularly a pain because at work I sometimes have to do videos showing my hands in action.  I had to use dark red nail polish to cover the discoloration, whereas a simple clear polish is what we'd prefer to have on camera. I also have one toenail that turned completely purple and I can't tell if I will lose it.  That's in addition to a second toenail that I do expect to lose from running.  This situation is making me reluctant to get a pedicure, but I'd dearly love to get one! Since the initial chemo hair loss, I've had a head of mostly peach fuzz.  I have just a couple of random white hairs that have grown up to an inch long, but are more or less invisible.  I am not counting on any appreciable regrowth until late summer/early fall at best.  I'm wondering how long I'll tolerate the wig now that that weather is starting to get warmer!  I really want to get my wig cut, but I'm nervous about it, because of course it won't grow back!  Does anyone know how feasible it is to do?  (Maybe I should also post that question elsewhere....)

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 08:23AM citykitty wrote: Christine47, you mentioned Xanax?  It helps with the crying moments?  That sounds like it would be nice on occasion.  Who prescribed it - your onc?  I've never taken any kind of tranquilizer, and the only sleeping pill I've taken is Tylenol PM, so I don't know at what point a little pharmaceutical intervention is considered worthwhile? Bdavis -- I too heard that some women get a growth of facial hair after chemo.  My onc said maybe someone was referring to the hair growth that can accompany menopause/chemopause. I'm holding my breath.  Wouldn't it be the icing on the cake to lose the eyebrow hair, and yet grow new hair below the brows?  Ugh! ScienceGirl - Hair growth!  Really?  Tell us more!  And I'd love to hear more about acupuncture.  What happens during a treatment?  How does it work?  Do you feel the results immediately?  Tsundermann - Congrats on being done with chemo!  So nice you had a big celebration.  I'd love to have one of those.  But then, the end of chemo was not such a big deal for me.  It may sound crazy, but I actually enjoyed going for my weekly treatment and having to do nothing but sit there while people took care of me.  I always said chemo day was the most relaxing day of the week -- such a change from the stress at work!  I'm sure I'd feel differently if the treatment and side effects had made me miserable! ProudMom_Wife - Oh, good point about the nose drips!  I haven't noticed them so much in the past few days...but then I've been away from work with implant exchange...  Also, the nosebleeds stopped pretty quickly after I ended Taxol.  Yay for that! JulieH - Your vacation plan sounds so great!  We're trying to make some plans for Memorial Day weekend.  We have an airfare certificate that expires soon.  Thinking of going to Toronto - we enjoy city sightseeing.  But sitting on a beach sure sounds nice! SherryhuttRS - I couldn't agree more about the hair loss.  It is the toughest part.  I have a decent wig but I'm still uncomfortable in it, sure that every breeze is blowing the hair up to reveal it for what it really is.   And as you said, who cares, but obviously, we do!!  I would really like to go to a support group...might try it this week while I'm recovering from implant exchange if I'm mobile enough.  The one at my hospital is in the middle of the day, so any other time, I'd have to take a day off of work.  But often when I think of going to one I feel like I want to cry... not sure really why....(and really, I am NOT a crier in my "real," non-bc life!). Christine, I love the crown for last day of chemo!  Too cute!  And LOL about going to rehab after you no longer need sleeping meds. Julie, thank you for the vivid picture you painted of dreading another chemo.  I'm so sorry for you and everyone who had such a difficult time with it.  Sometimes I wish there was a way for other people to appreciate how rough this experience can be.  Even though I've been luckier with the chemo, I go to work and everything is sort of normal, and yet there's this whole side of my life that is anything but normal.  It's a strange way to live.    Bdavis, Christine - I have been going through a similar thought process lately.  I asked my onco if I'd be getting any scans or tests to see if there is any cancer remaining.  She said no, and my understanding is she said if you have symptoms, then you get screened.  Screening alone doesn't offer any appreciable benefits.  I also think I'm hearing we really don't know if we got it all, and there's no way to tell.  So I'm with you, how do you move on?  I guess you just do, because how can you keep dwelling on it, either?  Ugh! Lorenar - Gee, you've been through a lot.  Glad you found a doctor you are happy with, even if you can't yet go there full time. Mary Meg - So great to hear from you, but not great to hear how you're doing!  I love how you get through it all with humor.  Your posts always make me smile.  I hope you're able to get plenty of smiles into your own days, too.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2011 06:48PM - edited Nov 20, 2011 06:52PM by citykitty Hi, you all -- Wow, I've been away from this thread for so long.  It feels like old home week, seeing all the familar names and faces posting these days! I passed my anniversaries of my biopsy (Sep 2), diagnosis (Sep 8), and re-excision (Nov 4)...coming up on anniversary of my mastectomy, Dec. 1.  I like that as an anniversary date -- an easy date to remember and the day they got the rest cancer (although I feel I can never be 100% sure, even after chemo!). My hair is growing in thick and curly and a nice dark brown, pretty much as before.  It cracks me up when people tell me it's cute and it suits me, because I don't feel like myself at all in this 'do.  However, I'm happy to have hair at all!  It's definitely easier to take care of, and sometimes I do consider keeping it short, except it reminds me of having cancer, because if it weren't for cancer I wouldn't have the short hair.  I did lose my eyelashes a second time, but they're finally back, at least for now.  My nails still look awful to me, but I'm hoping as they grow out they'll get back to normal. Meanwhile, let's see.  I had my exchange surgery April 22 and was cleared to resume running at the beginning of June, at which time I promptly began marathon training.  In September we traveled to France, where I ran the Marathon du Medoc, which is more a 26.2-mile wine fest in costume than a marathon.  It was in my plan for the past two years to run Medoc as part of my year-long 50th b-day celebration, and no way was bc going to come between me and that race.  Despite taking a nasty fall toward the end of the race (not from alcohol consumption, but calf cramps), I had a fabulous time. Two weeks ago, on Nov. 6, I ran the NYC Marathon.  I had problems with my knee, stopped for medical aid three times, and ran with an ice pack on the knee from Mile 7 onward, but I finished!  That finish line symbolized for me the finish of a year of life with bc and its aftermath.  It felt like a real victory to complete the race. Last weekend, I had a work trip to Florida, where I worked crazy hours and also made my debut on a certain television home shopping network. Yesterday I had revision surgery, swapping out my implant on my mx side for a different implant that I hope will give me better symmetry in clothes.  My result was not bad before, but I'm hoping the change will make me little bit happier. I haven't made any Serious Life Changes -- yet.  I am thinking about looking for a new job, but that was something I contemplated even before bc.  I too have had my share of mental hiccups, and I don't know whether to attribute it to chemo, surgeries, Tamoxifen, or just old age (50!) -- but I've been afraid to mention it at work.  I don't want any potential new employer to even think I am not up to snuff.  Even if they don't hear it from my current employer, I fear somehow it will become a self-fulfilling prophecy if I even mention it to anyone!  In my current job I'm just very frustrated and stressed for many reasons.  Some days I tell myself hey, it's not bc, therefore I shouldn't sweat it.  But still, I pride myself on doing a great job, and I feel in my current situation I'm mostly set up for failure.  So I need to figure out what to do about that. My fantasies of Serious Life Changes don't end with a new job.  DH and I have talked (though not seriously, I THINK) about moving to France, or at least spending more time there.  Our two weeks there in September only whetted our appetites.  Two nights ago, I booked us another trip to Paris for a week in December!  (I needed a few thousand more miles to get Elite frequent flyer status, LOL!)  I also fantasize about roaming the country in an RV for a year or so.  We did a one-week RV trip in Arizona several years ago and had a blast (and managed to stay married!). OK, I am not intending to compete with MaryMeg for the Longest Thread Ever, so I'll end this for now.  Big hugs to all of you!  It's been so great to have a place to compare notes and share experiences with other people who understand what we're all going through!  Best wishes and health to everyone!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 07:00PM citykitty wrote: Hello!  January chemo for me, too.  I'll have Taxol and Herceptin weekly for 12 weeks starting first week of Jan.  Then, Herceptin every 3 weeks for the rest of the year.  I expect to start losing my hair around Feb and be nice and bald for my 50th b-day in early March -- not exactly what I had in mind for most of this year, but hey, we play the hand we're dealt!  I had a uni mx a couple of weeks ago with a TE, so will be undergoing expansions at the same time as chemo.  All in all, I feel pretty lucky, and am relieved that after months of waiting, a plan is finally falling into place.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 07:28AM citykitty wrote: Hi, all, just checking in.  I've been away for a while and haven't had a chance to catch up reading the rest of the thread. I started Taxol & Herceptin last week.  I was told I might feel jazzed up the next day from the steroids I was given, but I felt pretty normal that day and the next.  The third day I felt pretty weak but went to work.  The fourth day, still weak but a little better, but also some random pangs of muscle pain.  I thought muscle pain would be an all-over thing, but instead it was a bit like a pinball inside my body, very sporadic.  Today is day five, sort of back to normal, I guess. Hope you all are doing well!  Hope to have time to catch up soon.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 07:04PM citykitty wrote: Hi all -- I just cannot keep up with you on this forum!  Pages and pages and pages go by before I ever have time to read -- and by the time I finish reading, I have no time to write!  So tomorrow I'll catch up on reading about you on my iPhone while I'm in chemo.  Sadly, I won't be able to write, however, because for some darn reason you can't enter text on this forum with the iPhone.  And I forgot my laptop at the office.  But I will be thinking of you and catching up with you anyway! Jcoutee, I'm on Taxol and Herceptin, weekly x 12 weeks.  Tomorrow is my #4.  You haven't had any hair loss?  I started losing hair the day after #3.  It's coming out in droves every day in the shower, but I still have enough hair to not look unusual.  My doc said it would likely be a gradual thinning, and that's what I'm experiencing.  Not sure how much longer this will go on before I give up and chop it off!  Those of you who have buzzed your heads look so wonderful!  I can only hope to look like you!  This gradual hair loss is like the death by a thousand cuts!  Yet I can't bring myself to cut it all off while I still have enough to look semi-normal!  This weekend we're going to visit dear friends out of town.  I can't tell how much hair I'm going to have left from one day to the next, so I guess I'll have to bring my wig along, just in case! Oh, and thanks for the tips on Gaila and FranceLuxe.  My Gaila headwrap arrived yesterday, within days of my request.  FranceLuxe apparently has a 4-6 week lead time, but that gives me something to look forward to! Other than the hair loss, my SEs have been relatively mild.  A week ago I had a raging case of steroid acne.  My face looked like it had been visited with the dermatological woes of an entire high school sophomore class.  Not to exaggerate, but it felt and looked pretty horrendous.  Thankfully, a visit to a dermatologist and a few days of prescription lotions and potions did wonders.  Now I just have dry skin (which is normally on the pretty oily side).  I also have two weird lesions, one each on my lower legs.  At first they looked like pimples or ingrown hairs, but they are not improving.  The dermatologist prescribed an antibiotic ointment for the first one (this was before the second one erupted).  As a runner, I'm nervous about anything going wrong with my legs.  I have visions of these things becoming infected and requiring surgery, but I'm sure it's nothing that extreme!  Tomorrow I'll have my onco take a look and then probably back to the dermatologist next week. I envy those of you who are taking time off work -- sort of.  I guess I'm lucky not to have SEs that require me to do so.  I technically could take the time, but I can't justify it to myself, feeling as well as I do most days and knowing I have freelancers who are picking up a good deal of my workload.  I am taking off Fridays for chemo, and so far I've taken off Mondays just because the first Monday I worked when I felt horrible, and I don't want a repeat of that.  So I guess taking off part-time is my compromise.  (But frankly it's a bit stressful to have to work out with my employer what my status will be each day -- disability?  FMLA?  time I will make up? -- especially when I have other doctor appointments that take me out for half-days on some of the remaining days when I would be working!) Otherwise things are mostly good.  I have occasional moments of feeling sad, but for the most part I try to make light of things (like losing the hair!).  I've been able to resume running and I did a half-marathon last weekend, albeit slowly. OK, it's past my bedtime.  Big day tomorrow.  Going to try to get in a little run if the roads aren't too icy, then off to onco and chemo!

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 07:01PM citykitty wrote: tsundermann -- I'm with you.  I'm 5 1/2 weeks post final chemo, and I have about two eyebrow hairs left on each side, virtually no lower lashes, and the last few upper lashes are hanging on for dear life!  Yikes!  My eyeliner and eyebrow pencil are my best friends!  The eyebrow pencil is the one I received at the Look Good, Feel Better class.  I never needed one before with my thick brows -- what a change. What's really odd is that even though the old hairs are dropping like flies, the new ones are growing in right behind.  I actually plucked eyebrow hairs this morning for the first time in at least 3 months.  And I think the hair on my head is starting to make an appearance -- a process I look forward to and dread at the same time.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 05:33PM citykitty wrote: Has anyone had their skin break out?  Around day 6 of my first weekly Taxol + Herceptin treatment, I had a couple of pimples and a patch of bumps on my face.  I was told it was from the steroids.  Then I had my second treatment.  Now 2-3 days later, my chin is completely covered in red bumps and white pimples, and I have a bunch of them all over my face, too!  Augh!  I think this has to be worse than going bald -- at least we have wigs for the latter!  I don't think any amount of makeup is going to help this skin, which looks like a miniature version of the Rocky Mountains.  I called the nurse and she told me to go to a dermatologist, so I have an appt for tomorrow.  In the midst of this I also am wig shopping (such drama, so hard to do) and trying to work out with my employer an arrangement so I can work when I'm able and go on temporary disability when I'm not.  Geez, just when I thought all the major stress was behind me, it's still here! JulieH - You had the guts to do what I have not done - gone red!  I was going to do the same as you, for the same reason.  I had already cut my hair, not super short, but much shorter than it was.  After going wig shopping, however, I began to wonder how smart that was of me.  My wig is likely to be longer than my short hair is now.  I'll look like I grew 6 inches of hair overnight!  Oh, well, I guess it's not like anyone who knows me doesn't already know what's going on!  My doc said I might not lose all my hair, so it will be an interesting time the next few weeks. Aimster - Ugh, I feel for you.  Glad they were able to hook you up with those anti-nausea meds. Islandmom - I've heard it takes 21 days to form a habit, but frankly, for exercise, I think it takes a bit longer!  I'm a dedicated runner now, but only became so a few years ago.  I had to find a way to make exercise fun for me.  Running with my iPod did the trick, and then as I built up distance and speed, I enjoyed seeing my improvements.  Before that, I used to work out on my stationary bike watching recorded episodes of Oprah.  In both cases, I committed to get up at a certain time, brush my teeth, and just put on my exercise clothes as part of the morning routine.  By the time I did that, I was starting to be awake enough to make myself move!  (I have since run a few marathons, and am hoping to complete a half-marathon next weekend, albeit at a slower pace than normal.)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 07:05PM - edited Feb 2, 2011 07:12PM by citykitty Hi, all - Sounds like there's a whole lotta buzzing going on!  Well, allow me to join you! It's been an interesting past few days!  My hair started thinning last Saturday, Jan. 22. By Friday the 28th, I had lost a LOT at the temples and the front.  The longer hair on top covered the bare spots, kind of like my late dad's bad combover, LOL.  Sat a.m. we took the train to Alexandria, Va., and I decided to wear the wig all day for its public debut, including our good friend's 60th b-day party. By that evening my scalp was sore, and not just from the wig. I was losing so much hair daily that cleaning it up doubled my time to get ready in the morning.  By Sun a.m. I was DYING to have my hair cut off.  I was really hoping for a buzzing party with our friends (like tideknott's), but that didn't work out.  On the train home, I wore a scarf on my head, which felt better than the wig at that point.  We got home at 10 p.m., and then, tired as we were, I had DH take a pair of scissors to my head and put me out of my misery!  It felt so good to be free of that mess! I had him leave it long enough -- about 2 inches -- so that it could be refined by a professional. The scalp was still quite red and tender.  I ended up going in to my stylist Monday, and he had it looking nicer but even shorter!  I planned to keep it that way for a couple of days and enjoy the novelty, but I had an appt to take my wig in Tuesday.  With the shorter cut, I didn't have much hair left to anchor the wig with the combs that were attached to it. The wig stylist said if he buzzed my hair, I could then anchor the wig with tape. I had thought I'd be doing that in a few more days, but in the end, I had it buzzed. So Tuesday's haircut lasted all of 24 hours. Oh, well -- plenty of time for short hair when it grows back in.  So for me, it was about a week from "uh-oh, there goes the hair" to "take my hair, please!"  Now, I'm pretty bald!  And we're not talking cute bald, we're talking patchy and pimply bald!  At least the soreness is a bit better today.  Oh, and yesterday we also went to a breast reconstruction class, and then I saw the dermatologist about my steroid acne and a couple of weird ulcerations on my legs that she (derm) thinks are caused by the chemo. Having cancer can be a full-time job, I'm tellin' ya!  (BTW, I think I too am on my way to the free Brazilian.  That was my first thought this a.m. when I got undressed to get in the shower and found a lot of hair in my undies!) Tomorrow I'll be going to work for the first time with my wig.  I think most people I work with are already prepared for it, so I don't expect a lot of people to be fooled.  But my wig even fooled my dermatologist!  She complimented me on the new 'do and was genuinely shocked to learn it was a wig! About my wig -- I went to at least three different places before I found something I felt I could live with.  The only one I thought looked at all natural on me and my somewhat big head was a human hair wig.  I have to say, the price was sky-high, but for me to feel confident, it was worth it.  I'm still holding my breath to see how much of it insurance will cover.  Yes, I know human hair is more work than a synthetic wig - but it's still less work than my own hair, or at least it should be.  I'm supposed to take it in to be washed and styled about once a month.  That's nothing in my book; it would take me at least 30 minutes a day to wash, comb, and blow-dry my hair, plus touch up the ends with a curling iron. As far as alcohol - the pamphlet from my hospital advises against it.  But when I asked my onco if I could at least have a glass of wine on my 50th birthday (one month from today!), she said yes.  And actually, at the weekend birthday party I had a few sips with the blessing of two MDs who were present!  I couldn't pass up the opportunity to try Opus One and Veuve Clicquot - I'm sure it will never happen again in my lifetime! This post is already way long....so stand by for the next one!

Jcoutee -- Where do you stay when you go to Mardi Gras, and how far in advance do you book? I'm a Tulane grad, but have not been to a Mardi Gras since I was in college (back when dinosaurs roamed the earth) - though I did run the Rock ‘n' Roll Mardi Gras Marathon last year!  I thought it was a strange name, because it took place well after Mardi Gras....  I want to go back for Jazz Fest sometime, too!  p.s.  You and I started our Taxol weekly x 12 on the same day! ScienceGirl, webu -- I've been on the weight rollercoaster, too!  I'm glad I lost a few pounds before and after my mx.  I figure it gives me a little "wiggle room" for the weight I anticipate gaining.  I sure would love it, though, if I could stay at my current weight.  I'm down 10 pounds from my norm, and down 6 from what I used to think was perfect for me.  But it has fluctuated quite a bit from day to day. JeanH -- Thanks for the tip about the iPhone!  I have been able to post from there - yay! Ck_ moma -- I can't believe you were pushing the car in the Thundersnow, yikes!  We saw that snowstorm on TV, just before our trip down to Alexandria a few days later. Lorenar -- So sorry you aren't doing so well.  Hope you're feeling better soon! Moe0279 -- Gee, I hope you are better soon.  Thanks for posting and giving possible insight for those of us who are following you in a week or two!  I felt a little tired this morning, which I've never felt on Wednesday before.  Hoping it's not a precursor of things to come. Backpage -- I love your "smoothies, movies, naps, friends!"  I would love to fit in more of all of those.  Hsgray -- Yikes!  Glad to see you back.  Whenever I think of this thread, I think of you and your avatar, because your buzzed head is so cute.  Ugh, so sorry about your veins!!  And having to stay away from your family!  And your onco was in Egypt!  Gee whiz, what a time you've had!  Hope things are getting better for you. Amelia2 -- I've never heard of wigs on wheels, what a great idea! ScienceGirl -- So you went to work with a scarf!  I haven't yet decided if I will do that.  Actually I'd love to go commando, but I'll probably go with the wig for a while.  JulieH -- Congrats on the new cut!  It looks great!  And as always, thanks for this thread.  You do such a great job of keeping up with everyone and welcoming the newcomers!

Posts.Content: May 19, 2011 06:35PM citykitty wrote: christine47, thanks for the tip about the Jergens foam tanner.  You put it on your head?!  That's a great idea.  Yes, the TE is definitely more natural than the expander!  If you haven't been to the Exchange City thread yet, you might want to check it out.  What I learned the hard way, but what others noted after me, is that when you take your first look after exchange surgery, you should "peek but don't freak!"  Maybe it's because I had a unilateral mx/recon, but I was dismayed at my result at first.  I didn't want to be too big, and I was afraid that in fact I did end up that way.  It took me more than a week to come to terms with it.  Some of it was just swelling, as it turned out.  I have since been told (by others on this board who are in a good position to know) that my result is really excellent.  And I am now fine with it -- just getting through a few more weeks of wearing funky bras before I get to wear a normal one again! tfinn, congrats on finishing chemo!!! ProudMom, congrats on the stubble!!!  Yay, we are getting there! Last weekend a photographer friend of mine did some photos of my DH and me -- with the wig and without!  I wanted to capture this part of the cancer experience.  Even though it's not a time I am enjoying, I think down the road it will be good to have photographic evidence of what this time was like.  The photos are really great.  I was going to post a couple on FB...but then I learned that future employers might not be interested in hiring a former cancer patient...which is not information I would volunteer, but of course they could see it on FB, so now I'm thinking maybe I should be lying low on that subject!  I'm employed right now, but you never know when a job change could happen. BTW, the Cancer and Careers website is a good resource.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2011 03:10PM citykitty wrote: Hi, all!  It's been a long time for me, too! Lorenar - Congrats on finishing Taxol!!  Did you lose eyebrows & eyelashes?  Don't be surprised if they fall out a couple of weeks after your final Taxol -- at least that's what happened to me.  But then they started growing back just as quickly as they left! Bdavis - I've been thinking about you and wondering how your surgery went!  Hope you heal well.  Wow, you went for a trim?!  Amazing!  My hair is up to about 1 inch all over, and I finished chemo at the end of March.  I don't think I'll be going for a trim for quite a while.  The short hair style is not "me," but at least it almost looks intentional now. I'm on Herceptin every 3 weeks for the rest of the year, and of course Tamoxifen.  This week I have my first appointment with my BS since the MX follow-up in December.  I also have a follow-up with my PS, for whom I definitely have some questions.  But otherwise life is "almost" back to normal.  The peripheral neuropathy seems to have ever-so-slowly dissipated -- I have just a tiny tinge in my fingertips sometimes.  I'm up to running 14 miles in my marathon training.  In early Sep I will run a marathon in Bordeaux, almost a year to the day of my BC diagnosis (an unplanned coincidence!).

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 07:27PM citykitty wrote: Jcoutee - Thanks for the info about NOLA hotels. I was just looking at the Jazz Fest website the other day, but not sure I can swing it this year. Would love to get down there for Mardi Gras again sometime. We shall see!  You were told only 1 drink a week after chemo? Yikes. I'm not drinking during chemo except for a couple of sips of a special wine a couple of weeks ago, and I'll have a glass for my 50th bday next month. After chemo, though, I plan to resume enjoying wine tasting, including a trip to Bordeaux in Sep.  ScienceGirl -- So funny you found you're not a wig girl. I'm the opposite. My wig makes me feel almost normal, although it's far from perfect. I shopped a lot to find one I could be comfortable in. It is actually thinner than my real hair was, and I don't like that. But wearing it, I feel like I look less cancer-patient-like and more like myself. I have a couple of scarves, but so far they're getting little use. At home I mainly go commando, even when sleeping.  UTMom - Ugh, sorry about your hospitalization!  I hope things get better for you. BTW, I used to live in San Antonio, and I have a real soft spot for Austin and UT! A lot of my high school classmates went there.  Tideknott/Beckie, your head looks great! I love your account and pic of your head-shaving party. You are very lucky to have done it the way you did, with lots of family and friends! Webu, your comment about your dog made me laugh!  I can empathize -- I do a double-take whenever I see my own reflection!  I don't recognize myself either bald or with the wig! JulieH, so glad you're doing better. The nausea must be awful.  1Miclon - Welcome to the group and sorry you have to be here. So sorry for the loss of your husband. I can only imagine how terrifying it must be to be diagnosed yourself after losing him. Hang in there. We have a great group here and I'm glad you found us.  Renrel - Thank you so much for your kind words and encouragement. I'm having difficulty making time for everything -- all the cancer stuff and all the regular life stuff. But we continue to plug along! Tfinn, you look awesome!  Isn't it a relief to have that hair gone? Sounds like your scalp is feeling better, lucky you! MaryMeg, you never cease to crack me up. "Whacked by the 'take a nap' bus" had me LOL!  Hope you're feeling better!  BTW,  I never heard we were supposed to Have Goals During Cancer. I was told to "practice extreme self-care." But I'm feeling too busy and stressed for that most of the time.  DancingMom, welcome!  Glad you found us. We're all helping each other get through this! Sherry, thanks for sharing the story of the survivor who reached out to you. Good to know she made you feel better. I hope we will also be able to pay it forward that way someday! Amyk -- (((hugs))) to you. Please don't feel like a wimp. I felt that way, and I'm on Taxol and Herceptin, which from what I'm reading here seems to generally have less severe SEs than some other treatments. Everyone is different. Hang in there. And I agree, see if you can't get some help for your SEs. BTW, you may already know this, but if you have a metallic taste when eating, I hear it helps if you switch to plastic utensils.  As for me -- Taxol + Herceptin wkly x12, then Herceptin every 3 wks x 9 months. Today I completed #6 of weekly Taxol + Herceptin.  My scalp is still itchy and sore two weeks after those symptoms began and I had my hair buzzed off. It's also covered with acne, ugh!  I've been using Head & Shoulders on the recommendation of moe0279. I'd love to try the jojoba oil or shea butter some of you have mentioned, but I'm afraid it would exacerbate the acne. I too have been using the lint tape roller on my head!  In the past few days my remaining hair has thinned visibly and I'm finally starting to get closer to the truly bald look.  My main SEs have been the acne and my two leg lesions. I've had occasional tingling and burning sensations in my hands starting around week 4. I've also had light nosebleeds most mornings starting around week 4. And, of course, there's the fatigue -- the feeling of my arms and legs being very weak. That happens mainly on day 3, but it happened two other days this past week on days when I expected to feel good. That really threw me, and now I feel my life is totally unpredictable.   My Decadron, which I get by IV before the chemo, has been reduced to almost nothing. Today at my request the Benadryl was cut in half -- yay!  I'm now officially halfway through the "main" part of my tx.  Here's to plugging along!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 09:21AM citykitty wrote: Hi y'all.... I've been away too long! I've been reading all the posts and thinking of you. Sorry it's difficult to do personal notes to all from my iphone. I can only echo what others have said: welcome to the newbies but sorry you have to be here. Thinking of everyone in NZ, especially our dear MaryMeg. Lots of hugs to those of you dealing with difficult SEs. A few random things from me... Last week I had my final tissue expansion. Now I live with this baseball on my chest for another 8-9 weeks, and stuff the other side of my bra, till exchange surgery near the end of April. Today I am sitting in tx #8 of 12 weekly Taxol & Herceptin -- after that, I'm 2/3 thru this phase of tx! Then I go to Herceptin every 3 wks x 9 mos + Tamoxifen x 5 yrs. SEs are fairly stable for me. A bit of steroid-induced acne persists. Nosebleeds in the a.m., which are now also occurring before I go to bed. Some neuropathy in fingertips and toes, and outer sides (pinky sides) of hands and feet. Fatigue is starting to have its cumulative effect, especially when I'm running (which is one of my big things in life). Some mornings I wake up very tired, but feel better after a few hours. No pain (thank goodness!), no nausea, no constipation or diarrhea. Oh, hair. It hasn't all fallen out, though it has thinned significantly, even after buzzing it a few weeks ago. I was sort of hoping to experience the completely bald look, because the Sluggo look doesn't do much for me. (Hope I'm not dating myself with the Sluggo reference -- the comic strip character who has about five hairs sticking out the top of his head, as best I recall.). I shave my legs mainly for doctor visits, but regrowth has been minimal since about week 2. Sadly, the eyelashes have thinned, but are not gone completely. My eyebrows have also thinned a little, but in my case that's not a bad thing. (Same can be said for hair elsewhere on my body; apparently I'm not quite headed for the full Brazilian, after all.) Not only are my brows not so dense now, but I haven't had to pluck in forever. I used to fight a daily battle against new eyebrow hairs. No more! :) Anyone else having mood swings or anything like that? I've had a couple of episodes where I just wasn't myself, and felt like I lost perspective and I got really upset and teary over something small. The last time I remember feeling this way is when I was about 14 years old and miserable! I don't know if this is related to menopause or chemo or both. I'm 49 (for a few more days), so right at menopause age anyway. I'm envious of those of you who are traveling. It's virtually out of the question for me with a weekly chemo schedule. I'm missing good trips for work! Bummer! However, I am going on a girls' weekend trip to a nearby ski area starting this evening. If I'm up to it tomorrow, I'll ski a little (taking care not to fall and damage my tissue expander). Otherwise I'll enjoy just hanging out. I registered for the Marathon du Medoc in September in the Bordeaux region of France. Have been planning this trip for two years, and now all chemo and surgery revolves around getting done ASAP so I can begin marathon training!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2011 06:14PM citykitty wrote: Kim congratulations on the chili award!  Care to share your recipe?? Here's my experience with Taxol and Herceptin weekly x 12, week 9, day 3. My pre-meds are Decadron, Zantac, and Benadryl, all administered by IV right before the Taxol and Herceptin.  I lost most of my hair around day 15, but still have a few hairs lingering on my head.  My lashes and brows thinned, noticeable mostly only to me, I think.  Otherwise my main side effects have been acne and neuropathy.  The acne was attributed to the Decadron, and over the subsequent weeks my dose was reduced to, as the doc says, "almost nothing."  (I went from 20 mg to 12 to 6 to 2mg.)  My skin has improved with the help of a dermatologist; now just trying to clear up some redness and the occasional pimple.  The peripheral neuropathy -- tingling in my fingertips and toes -- started around the third week, about the same time as I started losing my hair.  So far it's been only mildly distracting, not debilitating.  I was able to get my Benadryl dose cut in half, so I'm not totally zonked after chemo.  I even stayed awake the entire time the last two treatments!  I've had no nausea and no pain -- and I hope the same for all of you who are switching to Taxol! I'm targeting my exchange surgery for April 22; just waiting for the hospital and insurance to do their dance, which takes forever.  Will be really happy to get this baseball off my chest and not to have to stuff the other side of my bra to match.  After that, and 4-6 weeks off running, I'll be ready to start training for two marathons in the fall! This past Wednesday I celebrated my 50th birthday.  I wanted to do a milestone run, but 50 miles seemed rather out of the question!  In fact, even 15 was not seeming likely.  I decided I'd settle for 5, but in the end, I ran 10 miles, the longest I've run since my half-marathon the day after chemo #3!  I was really happy, because lately I've been starting to feel the cumulative fatigue of chemo and running has not been as easy for me.    Later that day, DH took me to a Broadway matinee performance of "Billy Elliott."  Then we went out to a fantastic dinner at Babbo, where we did a full tasting menu with wine pairings -- one of the few times I've indulged in alcohol during chemo.  I received lots of flowers and cards -- in fact, apparently Shoebox makes about five different cards for 50th birthdays, and I received each of them in multiples, haha! Today I ran a 5K -- my first race in my new age group, and my first race with no hair under my hat!  The combination of a hilly course, rain, old age, and chemo should not have made for a good race, but I did much better than I expected to, so I'm very happy about that! To say everything is wonderful, however, would be painting a false picture.  In the midst of all this came a reminder that not everyone is so fortunate.  A relative (by marriage) was recently diagnosed with what I take to be colon cancer metastasized to her liver (not totally sure).  Her health deteriorated quite rapidly, and sadly, she died only a month or so after we first learned of her situation.  I didn't know her well, but she was younger than I, and clearly well loved by her family and members of her church.  I'm struggling with how to process her death while still dealing with my own cancer.  It was just one of those times when once again, I was reminded how suddenly things can change.  And once again, I can only think, "There but for the grace of God go I," and remember to be grateful for every little thing. Not to end on a sad note, though, I wish everyone all the best as we continue to plow through chemo and surgery and whatever else they want to throw at us.  One of the many things I'm grateful for is this forum, where we can share, compare notes, and know we're not the only ones going through this!  Hugs to you all for being here!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 12:21PM citykitty wrote: Hi all -- Congrats to everyone who is finished/finishing with chemo!  MaryMeg & Julie, so nice to see you back! Taxol + Herceptin weekly x 12 weeks, week 10 I'm in the home stretch, with two more weekly Taxol + Herceptin treatments to go.  Then I switch to Herceptin every three weeks, and also will start Tamoxifen around the same time.  It sounds strange to say, but I think I'll miss my weekly chemo time.  I tell DH it's the most relaxing day of the week for me.  None of the stress from work.  All I have to do is show up and sit in a chair for a couple of hours -- nothing more is expected of me. I will be glad to see it end, though, because my SEs are starting to build.  I have more days when I'm more tired.  Today I didn't go to work because the fatigue was just too much.  It is still so frustrating and weird to feel wiped out one day and fine the next.  I feel like a wimp -- but I guess that's just how it is.  The neuropathy, which started around the third week and has been fine most of the time, is also starting to mount.  Now my feet feel the tingling/numbness along with my fingertips.  I've had days when I went for a run even though the entire bottoms of my feet felt numb.  I've also had a lot of twitching around my eyes, although my oncologist doesn't seem to associate that with chemo. DH and I are planning to go out of town next weekend, and I just hope I don't get there and then not feel OK!  An even harder call is the first weekend in April.  We are supposed to fly to Atlanta for a memorial service.  I'm nervous about committing to plane tickets, because what if I'm not up to it?  I just have no idea how I will be feeling two weeks after my final chemo treatment.  I might be fine -- but who knows?! Anyway, here's hoping you all are doing better and better as we get to the end of chemo!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 07:13AM citykitty wrote: Bdavis, the second wig sounds like a great idea.  I wish I had a second one, because sooner or later I need to send my human-hair wig in to be washed and styled, and I'm not looking forward to being wig-less for days!  I actually do have a second one I received for free, but the color and style are so not me, and I feel it looks so obviously like a wig that I can't bring myself to wear it in public.  Anyway, I hope you have a great trip and feel well the entire time! Julie H - Wow, 6 hours in the chair!  And Herceptin weekly for a year?  How interesting that even the same drugs can be administered so differently.  My first T+H was about 3 hours, and my H will be every 3 weeks for 9 months after I finish my 3 months of weekly T&H. On the MUGA scan -- pretty much what EmilyinOntario said.  They drew some of my blood out, mixed it with another substance, and re-injected it.  This "other substance" was radioactive and came in a lead box -- now, isn't that comforting, LOL?!  After a short waiting period (I forget, 20-40 minutes?), I was called back in and had to lie still for about 40 minutes while they maneuvered the scan machine into two different positions to get images of my heart.  Lying still is not a problem for me; I think I dozed off.  The whole process, start to finish, took maybe two hours. I am home from work AGAIN today.  I think this is the first time I've missed three days in a row just from chemo SEs.  I feel better than yesterday, and I struggled with whether to try to go in today.  The mental stress is as bad as the physical symptoms with this chemo thing sometimes!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 06:40PM citykitty wrote: Taxol + Herceptin weekly x 12, week 11, day 6  Hi all -- Final chemo tomorrow!  :)  I also have a MUGA scan tomorrow, my first since the baseline scan that was done when I started chemo.  More good news: my exchange surgery is confirmed for April 22.  I'll be so glad to get that done and recover (4-6 weeks) so I can begin marathon training! Thanks for the warnings about the SEs that can visit us AFTER chemo!  I had heard about neuropathy possibly increasing, but had not heard about possible increase in fatigue, loss of hair/lashes/brows, and other SEs after the completion of chemo.  Yikes -- seems like even when you think you have an idea of what to expect, every day is still a venture into the unknown! When my neuropathy crept from my feet to my shins and started interfering with my running, I called "uncle."  My onco prescribed Lyrica, and after a week, my neuropathy decreased substantially.  I still have tingly fingertips; I can live with that.  I asked about glutamine and the nurse said it was OK to take, but since the Lyrica seems to be doing an adequate job, I haven't pursued the supplements. My lashes and brows have definitely thinned.  With fewer lashes on my lids, my eyeliner really stands out.  My brows were pretty thick before, so I didn't consider the thinning to be a bad thing, but I just recently realized they really are different.  I started experimenting with an eyebrow pencil the past few days to fill in what's missing, and it makes a difference.  Amen to getting away.  Last weekend DH and I ran (not literally) up to Boston and just hung out.  It was nice to get a little change of scenery and forget about bc for a short while.  Of course there are always reminders.  The bangs of my wig were blowing in the high winds and I'm sure looked somewhat unnatural...but what can you do?!  Eventually I put on a hat and that held the bangs in place. Tanning...I've never done it (except the occasional day actually outdoors, LOL), but would love to get a little color!  I tan fairly easily but am trying to avoid too many UV rays.  I've thought about trying the airbrush route -- has anyone done that?  Pros and cons?  Last summer, at the ripe old age of 49, I wore a bikini for the first time in my life (yes, I have body image issues!).  Needless to say, my torso is pure white as the driven snow, in contrast to the rest of my body.  I would love to even things out and wear that bikini again this summer...(with a new and I hope slightly improved post-surgery bustline -- not larger, just a different shape).  Any thoughts on tanning, airbrush, etc.?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 05:46PM citykitty wrote: yorelh, I keep meaning to try the bangs or halo type of thing for running, but it wouldn't work for the office. Betsy, I remmber, you mentioned the shorter wig before!  I had such a traumatic time buying the first wig, and it was so darn expensive (even after insurance chipped in), that I have a hard time imagining buying another.  The only one I felt comfortable wearing at all is the one I ended up buying.  I have a shorter one that I received through Look Good, Feel Better, but the color and style are both way different, and I think it looks ridiculous on me.  Still, getting a second wig could be a lot smarter than cutting my main wig, so who knows, maybe in the end I'll get desperate enough to shop for another wig, after all....
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 14, 2011 03:24PM citykitty wrote: Betsy, Melissa, Jean -- Congratulations!  I am happy dancing for you!  Betsy, good luck in NOLA.  Hope you get to enjoy yourself a little on the trip. ProudMom, I am so sorry about your friend and about the tough situation you are in.  It just stinks.  As Julie said, we are here for you.  Vent all you want.  Lots of cyber-hugs headed your way. Christine47, that is tough news...it is absolutely not fair! Julie, thinking of you and your husband next week.  You are so right, it's always that unknown that is the most difficult. I'm 7 weeks past my final Taxol & Herceptin.  About two weeks ago (I think), I really started losing what was left of my eyebrows and eyelashes.  I had finally reached what I think of as that genuine space-alien look -- no hair, no eyebrows, no eyelashes.  And in answer to another post, yes, I lost more lashes on one side than the other!  No sooner did I lose those brows and lashes, however, than they started coming back with a vengeance!  I think my eyebrow pencil has just about seen its last use.  My brows are really getting dark, and with them came all the bajillion strays I used to pluck.  I was going to try getting them threaded, but I ran out of time and patience.  I picked up my tweezers last night for the first time in almost 4 months and went to town on the eyebrows!  My lower lashes are starting to make an appearance, so hopefully the upper lashes will follow soon.  And the hair on my head has gone from about 1/8 inch of almost invisible fuzz to about 1/4 inch of dark growth in the past 10 days!  Gee, I guess it's time to go check out that hair thread! Best wishes to all....

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 06:15PM citykitty wrote: MaryMeg, there you go, cracking me up again! I actually do Have Goals -- but they are the same ones I had Before Cancer. I have two marathons this fall -- but no Ironman. I like your goal, though. I want to be a floppy fish. Well, not really, but I did get to relax a little this weekend and it was really nice. Moe, I've had that tongue sensation for the past few days! I thought maybe I burned the tip of my tongue on hot tea or something. Thank you for mentioning it. Interesting that several of us have it. I was hoping it would diminish my appetite, but apparently not. After losing a few pounds the first four weeks on chemo, I'm now starting to see my weight creep back up. I knew it was too good to be true. I also have the morning nosebleeds. I think that's not unusual with Taxol (can't speak for other drugs). And I am also feeling a little sad this evening, which was not like me pre-bc. But these days who knows what's normal?! I'm not even sad about the bc, just other stuff in life. But I know this too shall pass. For Valentine's Day, I'm taking DH to a basketball game tomorrow night if I'm feeling ok. Isn't it crazy that we have to add that caveat to everything now?! I'm feeling horribly guilty I haven't yet made him a card, but hopefully I can squeeze that in tomorrow.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2011 07:56PM citykitty wrote: Hi all -- I've just been poring over the past several pages of this thread.  Thanks to those of you who have been posting pictures of your hair progress -- it's so encouraging! I completed Taxol & Herceptin x 12 on March 25, so I'm 7 weeks PFC.  Within the past two weeks I've gone from almost-invisible fuzz of about 1/8 inch (which is what I had throughout chemo) to about 1/4 inch of dark hair (soft as fur, Lago is right!).  My eyebrow hairs made a mass exodus around week 5 PFC, but now are coming back almost as quickly as they disappeared.  I used an eyebrow pencil for maybe two weeks in between.  My lashes disappeared right behind the brows and are also starting to come back.  I found early on I was definitely a wig person, not a scarf and hat person.  I had to shop around, but it was worth it to find a wig that made me feel more like myself, especially at work.  I finally worked up the nerve to go commando, or topless, just a couple of weeks ago -- just before my hair started growing back in!  It is a little weird with friends from my running group, who see me without the wig when we're running, but with the wig on other occasions!  People, especially newcomers to the group, who have seen me one way, don't recognize me the other way.  Then I have to go into the whole explanation all over again.  I've almost given up explaining except to say with a smile, "We met the other night.  I had hair then." Today a photographer friend took a few shots of DH and me, some bald and some with my wig.  I hope a few of the photos turn out OK.  I feel very lucky to have had the opportunity to capture this part of the journey in photos.  What we're going through feels like an eternity now, waiting for the hair to grow back.  I'm hoping to have a decent-looking short hairdo by this fall when we have a big trip to Europe planned, but who knows.  I expect it will be a couple of years before I'll feel anything like my normal, longer-haired self.  I look forward to a day when being bald is part of my distant past!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 09:23PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:26AM by citykitty It is definitely a tough decision, and every situation is a little different.  In my case, after a surgical biopsy showed I had both IDC and DCIS, I was given the choice of either lumpectomy + radiation, or mastectomy.  A post-biopsy mammogram showed I had additional DCIS still in my breast, and my BS said I had a 50-50 chance of getting it all with lumpectomy, or needing a mastectomy.  Well, we decided to go the conservative route first with the lumpectomy, but in the end I still had dirty margins all around and a relatively small breast, so in the end I needed a mastectomy, after all.  I wouldn't have done it differently.   For me the more difficult decisions came once I knew I would have a mastectomy.  Then I had to decide whether to do unilateral or bilateral, and reconstruction or not.  Everyone (i.e. the doctors) just assumed I'd do immediate reconstruction.  But I could not come to that conclusion myself until I researched my options and agonized over it.  I was not a candidate for flap reconstruction with my own tissue because they said I was too thin(!).  I had no family history, and no reason to think I would develop cancer in my healthy breast.  I think I could've been happy with bilateral mx with no reconstruction -- but in the end, I chose unilateral mx with 2-step reconstruction (tissue expander + implant).  Just had that surgery a couple of weeks ago.  I'll have the TE in for the next 3-4 months, then exchange surgery for my permanent implant. Good luck with your decision!!

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 07:40PM citykitty wrote: Hi all -- Zogo, Laurie, Julia, kcshreve (golly I hope I didn't miss anyone) -- Thank you SO much for your support, thoughts, and information.  It was a tough few days at the beginning of the week.    I'm not much of an outwardly emotional person, but I have never cried so much in my life as I have this week.  Between researching options and crying jags, I stayed home from work for three days.  Now it all seems a little silly.  Well, no, maybe not silly.  I just had to work through a process of coming to the right choice for me.  I did a lot of reading online, looking at pictures of reconstructions and not, and got to talk to a few women who had made various choices for themselves.  I did a lot of soul-searching, and then gradually the answer sort of came to me.  Guess it's gonna be unilateral mx with immediate reconstruction (TE followed by implant).  Even now, I still second-guess myself, but I'm pretty much OK with my decision. That was followed by a little drama when I learned some PSs at my hospital offer a wider range of implants than my PS does.  I like my PS and don't really want to switch, but I want to have all options available to me when it comes time to choose an implant.  They don't want you to switch PSs midstream, so for a moment there they had me scheduled to meet with a new PS the afternoon before my surgery!  I've heard some things about this PS's bedside manner that jacked my anxiety level way up. (Then I decided I wouldn't let hearsay bother me -- but I was still a little nervous.)  Also, my mom is planning to take a train halfway across the country to be here for my surgery, and now we weren't going to know till the day before the surgery if it would even still take place that day -- so she wouldn't know when to travel!  In the end, the hospital decided to proceed on schedule with my original PS, and possibly switch me to a different PS depending on my choice of implant.  Whew.  Now I can have the last few days before surgery a little more relaxed, and NOT filled with so much mental anguish!  I have a decision, I have a surgeon, and my mom can make her travel plans.  Did I say, "Whew?!"  I really feel this calmer mental state is going to help me get through the surgery better.  I have to go into the OR calm and sure of myself, not in a tizzy worrying about my choice or my surgeon or my mom or anything else!  Now I just have to get the house clean, pack a couple of things for the hospital, and work with DH to figure out if it's possible to fit both a Christmas tree and an inflatable bed for Mom in our tiny living room. Annie, having made my choice, I'm still a little envious of your decision (if one can be envious of the awful thing we all have to go through).  I wish I had the guts to do no reconstruction.  (I'd better be careful what I wish for!  Yikes, who knows, it could still happen someday!) Sohardbenme -- Wow, what a year you've had.  Lots of hugs and best wishes to you!! Mamabeth -- Welcome to the group.  You're the same day as me!  I'll be thinking of you Wednesday! Tammy -- I can so relate to the sudden tears out of nowhere!  I've had that quite a few times since my dx, even at times when I thought I was fine! OK, sorry this was so long!  Just wanted to share one funny thing.  I've spent a lot of time on the computer lately, pondering options, looking at pictures of reconstructions, and occasionally stumbling across things I wish I hadn't seen.  DH has started telling me, in the inimitable words of the Taco Bell chihuahua, to "step away from the chalupa."  LOL!  So now I am stepping away from the chalupa (but I'll be back!).  Best wishes to all you December gals!

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 08:33AM citykitty wrote: Just wanted to say I've had a wonderful experience with my care at MSK.  The red tape leading up to getting care can be daunting, but in the end it's been worth it to me. All the doctors and nurses have been kind and patient -- which means so much when you are feeling so fragile and vulnerable.  The facilities are immaculate.  I actually look forward to going there; it's a respite from my normal life and I feel incredibly well cared for.  Yes, sometimes the waits are long, but I know that when it's my turn, the doctor will spend as much time as necessary.  This really amazes me, because the doctor who did my biopsy, at another hospital, was always a bit short on time, and didn't explain everything to me the way my doctors at MSK did.  And MSK is always sending me patient satisfaction surveys, so you hope that means someone does care about that. The one area I've not had a good experience with is the red tape.  Because my insurance is out of network, any time I need a new appointment, it takes forever for MSK and my insurance company to talk to each other.  My insurance is really great -- they've covered everything and respond fairly quickly once someone tells them what kind of appointment or treatment I need.  But the process at MSK is very murky in terms of who talks to my insurance and how.  My approval for mastectomy came in at the 11th hour because of delays at MSK.  Waiting for this dance to take place when I was awaiting surgery (three times), and again when I needed chemo, was the most excruciating, most agonizing part of my entire cancer experience. Even after an appointment has been approved by everyone, whenever I arrive for my appointment, the receptionist has to call down to patient financial services before I'm allowed to check in.  It make me feel almost like a criminal. But once I'm through that hurdle, I'm good.  I'm seeing wonderful doctors.  Because it's a world-class facility, I don't feel I have to second-guess my care.  I feel absolutely privileged to be at MSK.

Thoughts, your experiences??

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2010 10:17AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:17AM by citykitty Welcome to all the newcomers, though sorry you have reason to join us! Tammy, what you heard was pretty much what I was told about the TE process and timing of exchange surgery.  I learned a little about the nipple recon on this board even before I met with the PS, so it wasn't such a shock when she told me ("they tattoo your what?!"  LOL!).  So funny because my DH abhors tattoos!  But I don't think he'll mind this one.  ;) So you had a PET scan.  How was it?  I would feel better if I had the rest of my body tested for cancer, but in the end my SNB (done at the time of my re-excision about a month ago) revealed my nodes are negative (YAY for that!!!), so I guess the chances are slim that I have cancer elsewhere. I took off work today, frantically tying up loose ends before tomorrow's surgery.  I haven't had time to cook and freeze food.  It's all I can do just to get the house somewhat straight.  But I did take time for a lovely run this morning.  Back in September I was training for a marathon when I was hit with a double whammy -- stress fracture in my right tibia, and breast cancer.  As a result, between the leg and two breast surgeries, I had to lay off running for about 10 weeks.  I just resumed running a couple of weeks ago, and haven't run longer than 5 miles since my marathon training came to a screeching halt, but today I did 10 miles at a pace that's pretty good for me!  It felt just wonderful!  And it's the last long run I'll get to do for a while now, so I feel very lucky and grateful that it was a good one!  All I can think about today is, this is my last day with both of my breasts!  What a weird feeling!

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 07:49PM citykitty wrote: ArleneMarie -- I was paranoid about constipation, even though I've never had problems before and have never taken a laxative in the past.  However, I did have problems passing the "pee" test so I could be released from the hospital, and had to have a catheter to drain my bladder.  Therefore I was paranoid that on my post-op visit I'd be queried about meds and bm's (or lack thereof) and be subjected to who-knows-what indignities (fears ALL unfounded, as it turned out).  To that end, I did all I could to make sure I "went" within 3 days or so of coming home.  I ate a few prunes a day, and on day 2 or 3 I took Miralax right before bed.  I also took advice I received to chug a glass or two of water, hot as you can stand it, first thing in the morning.  It's supposed to get things moving.  As I recall it was the second day of that routine where I had more success.  Good luck to you! It's so interesting to see all the different reports coming in.  I haven't been able to post much, but have been thinking of all of you here, especially the women who are having a tough time of it.  Lots of hugs and warm wishes to you!! I've been lucky.  Recovery has been pretty easy.  At the end of this past week, I had my first expansion with my PS.  I am now allowed to move on to the second set of arm exercises, including wall crawls and other movements to stretch above my shoulder.  I can start running again in a couple of weeks.  I also had my first appt with my oncologist.  I'll be having chemo (Taxol) for 12 weeks starting January, and Herceptin for the rest of the year...so maybe I'll see some of you over on the chemo TCH thread?  I've been only lurking there so far until I knew for sure what I'd be getting.  So -- I will be bald for my 50th birthday in March.  Oh, well.  I'm still pretty lucky!

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2011 11:10AM citykitty wrote: Hi, firedancer, zogo, Paula, and all!  Gee, it's like a mini Dec 2010 reunion!  I'm glad to hear you all are doing well. This time last year, I think I expected I'd be done by end of 2011, but I guess I will not quite make that deadline.  (BTW, I'm pasting some of this post from my post to the Jan '11 chemo thread.) I passed my anniversaries of my biopsy (Sep 2), diagnosis (Sep 8), and re-excision (Nov 4)...coming up on anniversary of my mastectomy, Dec. 1. I like that as an anniversary date -- an easy date to remember and the day they got the rest of the cancer (although I feel I can never be 100% sure, even after chemo!). My hair is growing in thick and curly and a nice dark brown, pretty much as before. It cracks me up when people tell me it's cute and it suits me, because I don't feel like myself at all in this 'do. However, I'm happy to have hair at all! It's definitely easier to take care of, and sometimes I do consider keeping it short, except it reminds me of having cancer, because if it weren't for cancer I wouldn't have the short hair. I did lose my eyelashes a second time, but they're finally back, at least for now. My nails still look awful to me, but I'm hoping as they grow out they'll get back to normal. Meanwhile, let's see. I had my exchange surgery April 22 and was cleared to resume running at the beginning of June, at which time I promptly began marathon training. In September we traveled to France, where I ran the Marathon du Medoc, which is more a 26.2-mile wine fest in costume than a marathon. It was in my plan for the past two years to run Medoc as part of my year-long 50th b-day celebration, and no way was bc going to come between me and that race. Despite taking a nasty fall toward the end of the race (not from alcohol consumption, but calf cramps), I had a fabulous time. Two weeks ago, on Nov. 6, I ran the NYC Marathon. I had problems with my knee, stopped for medical aid three times, and ran with an ice pack on the knee from Mile 7 onward, but I finished! That finish line symbolized for me the finish of a year of life with bc and its aftermath. It felt like a real victory to complete the race. Last weekend, I had a work trip to Florida, where I worked crazy hours and also made my debut on a certain television home shopping network. Meanwhile, I had not been thrilled with my perceived lack of symmetry.  My natural side was augmented with the smallest implant possible, but still looked larger than my mx side.  So on Nov. 19 (Saturday!) I had revision surgery, swapping out my implant on my mx side for a different implant that I hope will give me better symmetry in clothes. My result was not bad before, but I'm hoping the change will make me little bit happier. If that goes well, then I have to wait 3 months to do the nipple.  I'm planning on nipple-sharing using part of the nipple on my other breast.  Not sure about whether to tattoo or graft the areola; it's a whole conversation I haven't yet been able to have with my PS. Interesting you all mention the emotional aspect of all this.  As soon as you hear a dx of bc, you think, "emotional rollercoaster."  And yeah, I guess it has been that -- but not at all in the ways I expected.  I could write an essay on that subject alone, but I think for now I will just say THANK YOU to all of you for being here!  Lots of hugs and best wishes to everyone!  And if this post sounds disjointed, let's just blame in on the pain meds as I sit here recovering from my revision surgery!  :)
