Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 06:34PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 04:22AM by citykitty Hello all - I've been wanting to check in for more than a week now, but my mom came up for several days -- which was really nice, but made it difficult to break away to get online.  My uni mx with tissue expander was Dec. 1.  I've been amazed at how quickly I've been recovering.  My surgeon says some of that is attributable to my running. (I was training for my fourth marathon when I was struck with a double whammy of stress fracture in my leg and, oh by the way, breast cancer.) As a uni, I'm grateful to have use of one good arm to get through some of the daily matters of getting in and out of bed, washing up, and dressing!  Don't know how you BMXers manage!  I spent one night in the hospital and had a relatively good experience.  I was up most of the night with people coming in for this and that, and then a veritable parade of strange people in white coats starting around 4 a.m. to check out my apparently unusual T-shaped scar (long story).  The worst part, however, was not being able to pass the "pee test" to get released.  They had to insert a catheter (ugh!!!!) to drain my bladder, and I had to start from scratch.  It took hours of walking the halls and running cold water in the sink - and even using the Waterfall app on my iPhone (!) -- before I could "go." Within a couple of days I was walking outside, and five days after, I put on a bulky sweater and walked a mile (slowly and carefully!) to an evening meeting of my running club.  No one can believe I just had a mastectomy.  I set my iPhone alarms to remind me of my arm exercises (5x/day) and medications.  On Wednesday I went to a "Look Good, Feel Better" makeup class (Google for your local class -- very cool).  Yesterday I got my drain out (only had one!), and the surgeon said on a scale of 1 to 10, my skin-sparing surgery result is an 11!  Woo-hoo!  There was more DCIS remaining from my previous two lumpectomies (no surprise) but they got it out with clear margins!  Third time was a charm for me!  As of today I'm wearing a sports bra with a "fluff" to pad out the surgical side.  With the drain out, I feel amazing!  It's all I can do not to go out and run a few miles (forbidden for several more weeks)!  Of course in reality I'm still fairly sore -- but optimistic!  At the end of next week I meet with the PS for my first expansion and my onco to find out about chemo (I'm assuming I will have it). It's good to be back and see how everyone is doing.  I know I'll miss a few folks here, but I'm thinking of all our December group! takeadeepbreath - That visual of all of us as skydivers is great and so apt!  I was so tempted to do all that pre-surgery shopping.  But I kept finding myself buying things that were NOT useful for surgery, like form-fitting tops!  LOL! laugh-addict - So glad you're keeping a smile on your face!  That's my approach, too!  I even had DH take pix of me in the hospital.  Must have been the drugs, because normally I'm vain enough to never have my picture taken if my face and hair aren't done!  And ditto to your comment that even if we feel pain, it just means we're alive! oconnor2450 - Welcome back, so glad it all went well.  Congratulations on your big fat zero!  Woo-hoo! Warrior67 - Thank you for the view from the future.  Good to know there is hope that things will go well. Anniemomofthree - What a wonderful way to get your tree!  Thinking of you today and tomorrow as you go in for surgery.  Can't say if the hospital will be restful for you.  For me it was restful mainly when I was under for surgery!  After that, not so much!  LOL! thrmine - Sorry for your delay. Hope you recover from the trial drug and move forward! lciscarroll - Best of wishes - I'm thinking of you and your GAP.  I'll be interested to hear how you make out!  And thanks for all the interesting articles and links you come up with. zogo - Welcome home!  Wow, long surgery for you!  OUCH to all those IV pokes - you poor thing!  donnasb - Sorry you're having such a tough time.  I don't have much advice because my surgery was much different than yours.  I hope your PS has good news for you on the 16th.  Maybe you can find some advice on the Oct and Nov mastectomy threads?  Those folks will be farther along this journey than those of us with December mastectomies. fire-dancer - So glad you're home and doing well!  Take it easy! BikerBabe1 - Your surgery is similar to mine - uni with TEs.  I had my SNB a month ago.  The injection was no big deal.  My needle localization (don't know if you're having that) was briefly painful but it passed quickly.  I think you'll be fine.  Best wishes to you! Annie62 - So glad to hear you're doing so well!  Good for you!  Best wishes for a continued speedy recovery! For our December women coming up - good luck and best wishes for a surgery and recovery that are as painless as possible and filled with love and hugs!
